sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Carcinoma of stomach: optimal dosing and timing not yet defined
  • Colorectal cancer: optimal dosing and timing not yet defined
  • Glioblastoma multiforme of brain, Recurrent; as an adjunct to surgery: 8 wafers (61.6 mg) placed in resection cavity if size and shape of cavity permits; if cavity size and shape cannot accommodate 8 wafers, place maximum number of wafers as allowed
  • Hodgkin's disease, Relapsed or refractory, in combination with other approved agents: single agent in previously untreated patients, 150 to 200 mg/m(2) IV every 6 weeks (single dose or divided on 2 successive days); adjust dose for use in combination with other agents
  • Intracranial tumor, Malignant: glioblastoma, medulloblastoma, astrocytoma, ependymoma, or metastatic brain tumors: 150 to 200 mg/m(2) IV every 6 weeks as a single agent in previously untreated patients (single dose or divided into 2 successive days); adjust dose for use in combination with other agents
  • Malignant glioma - Neoplasm of brain stem: brainstem glioma: 150 to 200 mg/m(2) IV every 6 weeks as a single agent in previously untreated patients (single dose or divided into 2 successive days); adjust dose for use in combination with other agents
  • Malignant glioma of brain, High-grade, newly diagnosed; adjunct to surgery and radiation: 8 wafers (61.6 mg) placed in resection cavity if size and shape of cavity permits; if cavity size and shape cannot accommodate 8 wafers, place maximum number of wafers as allowed
  • Malignant melanoma: optimal dosing and timing not yet defined
  • Multiple myeloma, In combination with prednisone: single agent in previously untreated patients, 150 to 200 mg/m(2) IV every 6 weeks (single dose or divided on 2 successive days); adjust dose for use in combination with other agents
  • Mycosis fungoides: 0.5 to 3 mg/mL in 30% alcohol (extemporaneous formulation), apply TOPICALLY to affected areas 1 to 2 times daily for up to 8 week
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, Relapsed or refractory, in combination with other approved agents: single agent in previously untreated patients, 150 to 200 mg/m(2) IV every 6 weeks (single dose or divided on 2 successive days); adjust dose for use in combination with other agents
  • Waldenstroem macroglobulinemia: optimal dosing and timing not yet defined

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and effectiveness of carmustine have not been established in pediatric patients
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, Relapsed or refractory, in combination with other approved agents: consolidation and maintenance, in combination with other antineoplastic agents, 30 to 60 mg/m(2) IV; interval depends on regimen used

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• liver disease: dosage adjustment may be necessary based on liver function test results; no specific guidelines available
  • hematologic (injection): leukocytes 2000 to 2999 cells/mm(3) or platelets 25,000 to 74,999 cells/mm(3), give 70% of prior dose; leukocytes less than 2000 cells/mm(3) or platelets less than 25,000 cells/mm(3), give 50% of prior dose

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
Intravenous (Powder for Solution)
Carmustine for injection should be administered under the supervision of a qualified physician experienced in the use of cancer chemotherapeutic agents. Bone marrow suppression, notably thrombocytopenia and leukopenia, which may contribute to bleeding and overwhelming infections in an already compromised patient, is the most common and severe of the toxic effects of carmustine. Blood counts should be monitored weekly for at least 6 weeks after a dose. At the recommended dosage, courses of carmustine should not be given more frequently than every 6 weeks. Pulmonary toxicity from carmustine appears to be dose related, as patients receiving greater than 1400 mg/m(2) cumulative dose are at significantly higher risk than those receiving less. Delayed pulmonary toxicity can occur years after treatment, and can result in death, particularly in patients treated in childhood.

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• bone marrow toxicity, leukopenia and thrombocytopenia; increased risk with cumulative doses and concomitant cimetidine use; monitoring recommended (injection)
  • delayed onset pulmonary fibrosis (occurring up to 17 years after treatment) has been reported; increased risk associated with use in childhood (1 to 16 years) and cumulative doses greater than 1,400 mg/m(2) (injection)
  • pulmonary toxicity, pulmonary infiltrates and/or fibrosis, including fatalities; has been reported; increased risk associated with duration of use, history of lung disease, and cumulative doses greater than 1,400 mg/m(2); monitoring recommended (injection)
  • injection site reaction may occur; monitoring recommended (injection)
  • intraarterial intracarotid administration (off-label use); increased risk of ocular toxicity (injection)
  • intracranial hypertension causing brain edema and intracerebral mass effect has occurred; monitoring recommended (implant system)
  • liver dysfunction may occur; monitoring recommended (injection)
  • long term use; increased risk of secondary malignancy (injection)
  • meningitis has been reported; monitoring recommended (implant system)
  • necrosis of skin, following infiltration; has been reported (injection)
  • neurosurgical wound healing, impaired (eg, wound dehiscence, delayed wound healing, wound effusion), has been reported; monitoring recommended (implant system)
  • obstructive hydrocephalus due to wafer migration may occur; surgically close communications between resection cavity and ventricular system prior to implantation; monitoring recommended (implant system)
  • pregnancy; may cause fetal harm
  • renal abnormalities (eg, progressive azotemia and renal failure) have been reported with prolonged treatment of large cumulative doses; monitoring recommended (injection)
  • seizure, new onset or worsening, may occur; optimize antiseizure therapy prior to surgery and monitor postoperatively (implant system)
  • report suspected adverse events to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Constipation (implant, 19%), Nausea (implant, 22%), Vomiting (implant, 21%)
  • Immunologic:Impaired wound healing (implant, 14% to 16%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia (implant, 22%), Headache
  • Psychiatric:Depression (implant, 16%)
  • Renal:Urinary tract infectious disease (implant, 21%)
  • Other:Fever (implant, 12%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Chest pain (implant, 5%)
  • Hematologic:Leukemia, Leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia
  • Hepatic:Hepatotoxicity
  • Neurologic:Abscess of brain (implant, 6%), Cerebral edema (implant, 4% to 23%), Cerebral hemorrhage (implant, 6%), Cerebrospinal fluid leak (implant, 5%), Hydrocephalus (implant, 5%), Intracranial hypertension, acute (implant, 9%), Meningitis (implant, 4%), Seizure (implant, 54%)
  • Renal:Nephrotoxicity, Renal failure
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary toxicity
  • Other:Infusion reaction (87.6%)

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: Carmustine is an alkylating agent of the nitrosourea type. Carmustine and/or its metabolites alkylate and interfere with the function of DNA and RNA and may inhibit several key enzymatic processes by carbomoylation of amino acids in proteins.

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono: IV, 22 min, 1.4 min (1st phase), 17.8 min (2nd phase)

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
• General Information
    use proper procedures for handling and disposal of carmustine
  • Intravenous
    • contains no preservatives and is not intended for use as a multiple-dose vial
    • reconstitute first with (3 mL) of the supplied diluent (Dehydrated Alcohol Injection, USP), followed by addition of 27 mL of sterile water for injection, resulting in a concentration of 3.3 mg/mL; protect from light; reconstituted solution stable for 24 hours refrigerated (2 to 8 degrees C; 36 to 46 degrees F)
    • reconstituted solution may be further diluted with D5W to a concentration of 0.2 mg/mL; store at room temperature, protect from light, and use within 8 hours
    • accidental contact of reconstituted carmustine with the skin may cause transient hyperpigmentation of the affected areas; if drug (powder or solution) comes into contact with the skin or mucosa, immediately wash the area thoroughly with soap and water
    • administer in glass containers only
    • consider administering at a maximum infusion rate of 3 mg/m(2)/min; this increases the duration of the carmustine 450 mg/m(2) infusion to 3 hours to avoid high risk of infusion reactions
    • administer by slow IV infusion over at least 2 hours; monitor infusion site closely for infiltration

mono.title: Monitoring
mono.mono:
• clinical remission and/or evidence of tumor response is indicative of efficacy
  • (IV) CBC; weekly for a minimum of 6 weeks following a dose, including differential
  • (IV) liver function tests; periodically during treatment
  • (IV) renal function; periodically during treatment
  • (IV) infusion site; for infiltration during administration
  • (IV) pulmonary function tests; baseline and frequently during therapy
  • (implant) seizures; postoperatively
  • (implant) intracranial hypertension, in the brain tissue surrounding the resection
  • (implant) impaired neurosurgical wound healing; postoperatively
  • (implant) signs of meningitis and CNS infection; postoperatively
  • (implant) signs of obstructive hydrocephalus

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
NITROSOUREAS
OVERDOSE: Limited data. Effects are anticipated to be an extension of adverse effects. Severe delayed bone marrow depression has been reported following lomustine overdose. Other effects have included: delayed liver and lymph node enlargement, abdominal pain, ileitis, elevated liver enzymes, mental status changes and tachypnea following lomustine overdose. ADVERSE EFFECTS: BENDAMUSTINE: Hypersensitivity reactions (fever, chills, pruritus and rash) have occurred with therapy, but severe anaphylactoid reactions have been reported rarely. Myelosuppression is common, tumor lysis syndrome may cause renal failure. Rashes are common. CARMUSTINE: Hypotension, tachycardia and myocardial ischemia have been reported with high dose carmustine infusion. Thrombocytopenia and granulocytopenia are common. Pulmonary toxicity may develop after carmustine therapy and may be dose related. Effects are more commonly reported in women and may present years after therapy. LOMUSTINE: Delayed myelosuppression is the most common and severe toxic effect. Pulmonary fibrosis has developed. Acute renal insufficiency and failure can develop. Nausea and vomiting are common. STREPTOZOCIN: Renal toxicity may be severe. Nausea and vomiting are common. Hematologic toxicity is rare.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
NITROSOUREAS
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Decontamination: Consider activated charcoal following an oral exposure.
  • Myelosuppression: Administer colony stimulating factor. Filgrastim 5 mcg/kg/day subQ or IV over 15 to 30 minutes.
  • Nausea and vomiting: Treat with antiemetics.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor hematocrit, platelet count, total leukocyte count with differential, renal function, liver enzymes, and respiratory status.
  • Extravasation injury: Discontinue infusion. Local application of moderate heat may be beneficial. Monitor site for signs of necrosis or infection. Treat as a chemical burn.
  • Intrathecal injection: No clinical reports of intrathecal injection with nitrosoureas are available. This information was derived from experience with other antineoplastics. Keep the patient upright if possible. Immediately drain at least 20 mL CSF; drainage of up to 70 mL has been tolerated in adults. Follow with CSF exchange (remove serial 20 mL aliquots CSF and replace with equivalent volumes of warmed, preservative-free NS or LR). Consult a neurosurgeon for placement of a ventricular catheter and begin ventriculolumbar perfusion (infuse warmed preservative-free NS or LR through ventricular catheter, drain fluid from lumbar catheter; typical volumes are 80 to 150 mL/hr for 18 to 24 hours). Fresh frozen plasma (25 mL FFP per liter NS or LR) or albumin 5% have been used for perfusion. Dexamethasone 4 mg IV every 6 hours to prevent arachnoiditis.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
NITROSOUREAS
TOXICITY: LOMUSTINE: A patient survived an overdose of 600 mg orally for 15 days; delayed bone marrow toxicity occurred. Two patients survived an 800 mg dose of lomustine over 5 days, with both patients experiencing severe myelosuppression. An adult died of multiorgan system failure after ingesting 1400 mg of lomustine. BENDAMUSTINE: Limited data. The maximum single dose reported was 280 mg/m(2) with several patients developing ECG changes and QT prolongation. STREPTOZOCIN - Toxic and minimum lethal dose are not known. THERAPEUTIC: Varies with agent. BENDAMUSTINE: 100 mg/meter(2) IV on Days 1 and 2 of a 28-day cycle for up to 6 cycles. CARMUSTINE: 150 to 200 mg/meter(2) IV every 6 weeks. LOMUSTINE: A single oral dose of 100 to 130 mg/meter(2) repeated every 6 weeks. STREPTOZOCIN: 500 mg/meter(2) IV daily for 5 days every 6 weeks. A single dose of 1500 mg/meter(2) should NOT be exceeded.

mono.title: Clinical Teaching
mono.mono:
• IV: Advise patient to immediately report symptoms of pulmonary toxicity (infiltrates, fibrosis).
  • IV: Counsel patient to report symptoms of myelosuppression (thrombocytopenia, leukopenia).
  • Implant: Warn patient to report new onset or changes in seizure activity.
  • Implant: Side effects may include nausea, vomiting, constipation, asthenia, depression, confusion, and wound healing abnormalities.
  • IV: Side effects may include nausea, vomiting, extravasation, flushing, infusion reactions, and headaches.
  • Implant: Counsel patient to report symptoms of intracranial hypertension or meningitis.
